blocks.text: by discussing the simple case $y = 5x^2 + 17$ (a binomial or two-term polynomial). The curves $y = 5x^2$ and $y = 5x^2 + 17$ are seen plotted in Fig. 8, and an examination shows that the lower curve is the former moved vertically an amount equal to 17 vertical units. Thus, their slopes at corresponding points are the same and consequently, their slopes at corresponding points are the same.
If a tangent is drawn to each curve at the point for which $x = 2.5$, the slope of each tangent is measured as $25, 	ext{ i.e., } 25;$ and
subsequently the diagram informs us that the tangent 17 makes no difference to the slope.

It is seen that in this simple example it is a perfectly logical procedure to differentiate term by term and add the results; and the procedure could be equally well applied to all many-term expressions.
